column4: what's the difference between linux-generic and linux-686 and linux-386?
linux-generic is a superset of all other linux architectures. linux-386 is compiled for pre-pentium1 hardware.
linux-686, intended for pentium 4 and up, is one of the architectures obsoleted by generic.
it says that linux-686 is "obsoleted" by linux-generic...
I currently have generic, is it optimized?
Once upon a time there were many architectures! There were 386, 486, 686, amd-k7, and-k8, and many others!
And the ubuntu developers, lo, they looked upon these architectures, and they said: augh! We're too lazy to provide all these.
So they came together, and they crafted a great work; they toiled in secret on CVS and lo, they revealed their work to the world: it was -generic.
so generic can handle all types of architectures..but not necessarily optimized right?

And they said unto the people: hark! No longer will you have to install kernels for your subarchitectures to get features you want! Here is -generic, and it provides all the features you want without significant loss of speed!
And the people cheered, and the sun shone bright, and it was so.
You get lots of juicy technical details about exactly how optimised -generic is
thanks a lot arrenlex :) that really clears it up
